comments.body:
my personal preference is to stuff things like this into a fixture file and then load them using something like load_json method that I found (at one time, dunno if it's there anymore) in the nxos module unit tests.

Here's what it looked like at the time
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/test/units/modules/network/f5/test_bigip_hostname.py#L58

and then stuff the JSON in a `fixtures/` directory

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +36,40 @@        self.maxDiff = None

        expected_result = {
            u'error_code': u'401',
            u'error_text': u'Username or password is incorrect - FAILED local authentication',

@@ -1,1 +50,54 @@        }

        json_response = '{"totalCount":"1","imdata":[{"error":{"attributes":{"code":"401","text":"Username or password is incorrect - FAILED local authentication"}}}]}'  # NOQA
        json_result = aci_response(json_response, 'json')
        self.assertEqual(expected_result, json_result)

comments.body: fixture with load_json. If it's not valid json then load_json just gives you back a plain string

comments.body:
my personal preference here is to dump all of these 2.7 specific modules into a Test class that has a pytest decorator of @pytest.skipif(sys.version_info <(2,7)) or whatever the syntax is.

By collecting the version specific tests in their own classes, you can avoid this conditional logic in the test itself

It's not that easy, we have different input whether it is python 2.6, or depending on the version of a library. So I have "if X, elseif Y, else" constructs that seem to be harder to do with decorators. (Or at least could lead into unsupported test-cases)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +55,59 @@
        # Python 2.7+ is needed for xmljson
        if sys.version_info < (2, 7):
            return

comments.body: Another test that I would move into version specific classes with pytest skipifs
